caption: Considering the age of this Church, it is in a remarkable condition. The internal achitecture and statues are immaculate and well preserved. A delight to visit as it is so quiet and modest compared to the larger and much more famous neighbour around the corner. The entrance door in itself is a masterpiece of carving at such a time, given the basic tools available to the carpenters.

12th century iconic church which has seen a number of saints who have come to pray and meditate. Among them Ignatius of Loyola is one of them. A placard is placed on the wall to remember his contribution to the church through the society of Jesus which he founded along with his companions.
Chapel situated in Montmartre near Sacre Coeur and village square. It is known to be the second oldest surviving church in Paris. Very simple and tranquil inside. Free to enter.

This second oldest (12th century) church in all of Paris is worth visiting, especially if you are taking a tour of Montmartre. It is basically right behind the more popular basilique Sacre-Coeur de Montmartre, and lot less crowded.  You cannot miss but notice the beautiful art and detail on the bronze central doorway. The church displays a statue of our lady of Montmartre. It was nice and peaceful inside and we could take our time appreciating the beauty of the art and history of this place.

The church is free to enter.  We happened to arrive after lunch just as a tour, in English, was beginning (also free). The tour guide was excellent and extremely knowledgeable on the architecture and history of the building. This is a lovely hidden gem tucked in behind Sacre Coeur. Well worth a visit.
Second oldest church in Paris, not as touristy as Sacre Coeur, and can pray inside. Love this church.
I went to this church while living in Paris in November, 2016. It is known as the 'White Chapel' and this Church sits on top of a hill overlooking all of Paris. The view is absolutely stunning.
Just as you step through the gate, the temporary store is on the left. The hot wine was so delicious! The combination of all the spices was a very special experience.
Wonderful place to go I really enjoyed it so much .. fabrics are amazing you can by by meters and design it by yourself .. lots of cafe restaurants .. the cathedra is up
Small forgotten gothic church, no money for entrance but a great place for a quick chat with god when touring in Montmartre

Beautiful church steeped in rich history. A student/volunteer with excellent English gave us a fascinating tour. It wasn't busy the day we were there.  I think this gem could be overlooked in favour of Sacre Coeur. Keep an eye out for it, you won't be disappointed.
You don‚Äôt want to stay in line to get into the Sacre Coeur? Try this little √©glise next door which is celebrating its 870th birthday! You can also make donations by contactless card
A small church that is overshadowed by the Basilica, but is worth a visit.

The church is a really spare gothic church. Allegedly built in 12th century as one of the oldest church in Paris!! On this foundation was a church from at least 6th century. There was rumors that Paris‚Äô Saint St Denis was killed here in the 4th century? According Wikipedia, some columns apparently came from the Merovingian kingdom. There is no reason to not stop by if you are going to the ornate Saint Coer next door
A place worth to visit,  the cathedral and the village are so lovely.
Very romantic place with a charming atmosphere. Must visit in Paris if you are a couple!
Very nice very old Church from XII th Century, on Montmartre
Beautiful 12th century church. Crucifixes outside we‚Äôre spectacular but difficult to see from street.
Interesting place. Especially the 900+ year old cemetery.
Quiet church to escape from the tourists. Has some pretty stained glass windows and a statue of Saint Denis, typically carrying his own head.
I didn't go inside,  but I wish I had.  It's absolutely gorgeous.
Right in front of the church. You can get hot wine and hot chocolate here how nice in a cold night like this.
Go to tower. Entrence fee is 6‚Ç¨ but it is worth a lot more. The Greatest view.
Beautiful little church üôè ‚Ä¶

This church is a little bit of the beaten track as obviously everyone is going to Sacre Couer and many people go down after and don't discover this place. I was completely alone in this church which made the experience really worth. Outstanding colorful altar and vitrages are something definitely worth seeing!

This church is almost 900 years old, and the second oldest in Paris. Sitting in the shadow of Sacre-coeur, it is quite modest both inside and outside. Entry is free, though there isn't much too see and isn't particularly spectacular. Dress in appropriate modest attire when visiting.

This old church at the top of Montmartre is the one that the locals attend.  The history of a church at this site apparently goes back to the third century, and St Ignatius Loyola apparently took some vows here. The building is  Romanesque with heavy pillars supporting the vaulted ceiling.   There is some beautiful stained glass and evidence that the church is used on a daily basis.   Much quieter than the larger church right next door.

Breathtaking scenery at the top of the church. Overlooking the city of Paris. For sure a must spot for tourist. Can take a cable car down. Take your time to walk up the stairs as there is some other nice spot to explore while you walk up.

Beautiful. Lovely. Amazing inside. Peaceful. Outside had spectacular views. There was even entertainment by a guy performing amazing gymnastic, aerobatic stunts with his soccer ball/futbol. Worth the trip, especially with the outside entertainment
The real gem of Montmartre.  A 12th century church, still standing and in use!
Beautiful inside and outside worth going to see
A lot of stairs to reach the place where there are a lot of tourists, however the place is undeniably beautiful and the area around it is very pretty and quiet

The oldest cathedral on Montmartre - its building goes back to the 12 century. Very calm and cosy, with nice atmosphere. Long time ago there was an abbey, transformed into the cathedral. Nearby there is a cemetery, where sculptor Pigalle was buried.
Old monastery of the Butte, on which side the new church was built and stole all the attention; but former shrine still holds spiritual precedent. Vitrage, stone, glory. Must visit.

I know it's probably just me, but I really appreciated this church and my experience more than mine at Sacre Coeur, which we visited immediately before St. Pierre, the oldest Catholic church in Paris. It was much smaller and much more intimate a space. Fewer crowds accounted for it being quieter, but I appreciate the chant music playing softly as we looked at the niches and the relic of St. Therese that's available for public view. A lovely, often overlooked respite after the frenzy of Sacre Coeur, if you're looking for another church rather than a tourist spot, this is it.
Beautiful nearly 800 year old parish

Every restaurant around here charges you extra to sit on their tables. We wanted to have a coke and if you didn't sit it was two euros, but the moment they gave us the menu it was four euros...so of course we didn't have it. Also there's a lot of men who draw portraits and of course it's a scam. And they can be a little annoying, they don't give up on easily.
Calm & quiet church, hidden in plain sight among the crowds visiting the surrounding attractions. Worth the visit on its own merits, but also a nice place to stop in for some calm.
